newsitem.title: GERMANY: Buba's Krupp-EMU criteria need not be met exactly.
newsitem.headline: Buba's Krupp-EMU criteria need not be met exactly.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Hans-Juergen Krupp said on Thursday that the Maastricht Treaty on European Union did not require nations to meet the reference levels exactly.
"The matter is quite simple. The Maastricht Treaty was also ratified by Germany and stands, and as for the so-often discussed fiscal criteria, it does not require an exact fulfilment," Krupp said.
Krupp, also president of the state central bank in Hamburg, Schleswig-Holstein and Mecklenburg Vorpommern added

"The procedure is clear. According to the criteria which must not be softened, but whose leeway for interpretation will be used, the decision on which countries will take part on January 1, 1999 in European Monetary Union will be taken in the Spring of 1998."
European union leaders have repeatedly stressed that EMU starts on January 1, 1999.

"This date stands for the financial markets as well, and the forecast by the leading economic research institutes gives no reason to change this position as it explicitly pointed out the Treaty's room for interpretation".
Germany's six economic institutes forecast that Germany's budget deficit will reach 3.5 percent of GDP in 1997, exceeding the three percent reference target.
